repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - SIMAP / Health, Nutrition, Water
            and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project was
            rated as satisfactory. Some of the key lessons learned from
            the project include: 1) The absence of sector policies in
            nutrition, health, water supply, and basic sanitation
            adversely affected Social Impact Amelioration Program's
            (SIMAP's) operations and the sustainability of some
            subprojects. 2) Pre-selecting the subproject sites during
            project preparation significantly increased SIMAP's
            capability to timely implement the subprojects. 3) Greater
            emphasis should likely have been placed on subproject
            maintenance issues during project preparation when
            negotiating project sites with the Regional Administrations
            and related ministries. 4) Government agencies and
            communities responsible for the sustainability of
            subprojects executed through SIMAP should be more actively
            involved at all stages of the subproject cycle. 5) The short
            and long-term success of nutrition projects implemented
            through health centers is dependent upon the level of
            collaboration and commitment from the Ministry of Health
            (MOH). 6) Greater impact would have been gleaned from the
            nutrition interventions had project administrators
            emphasized greater coordination between the MOH and SIMAP,
            better coordination between food distribution and the
            rehabilitation of the health centers, and greater investment
            in nutrition education programs. 7) Implementation
            timetables should take into account the institutional
            capacity of the implementing agency to manage the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Social Impact Amelioration Program
            (SIMAP) / Health, Nutrition, Water and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the project is to
            assist the government in cushioning the social costs of the
            adjustment process through the establishment of an effective
            mechanism aimed at addressing the basic needs of the
            population in a decentralized manner, through such groups as
            nongovernmental organizations (NGOs). The project aims to:
            a) improve health and nutrition over the short-term; and b)
            assist in the formulation of sustainable policies and
            programs in the social sectors over the medium term. The
            project contains four components: 1) institutional
            development; 2) sub-project implementation; 3) establishment
            of a living standards measurement survey (LSMS); and 4)
            development of a policy framework in the health sector. The
            first component assists in the development of the Social
            Impact Amelioration Program (SIMAP) Agency.  The second
            component addresses basic health, nutrition, water and
            sanitation needs of the groups affected by the economic
            decline, especially pregnant and lactating women and
            children under age five.  Financing is provided for: i)
            rehabilitation of primary health care facilities; ii)
            nutrition education and food distribution programs; iii)
            construction of day care centers; and iv) installation of
            basic water supply facilities.  The third component involves
            development of a household survey. The last component
            includes financing of technical assistance to help the
            government develop medium term policies for the health sectors.
